title: Open Scholarship Community Sheffield
text:
Hi, I’m Neil Shephard, and I’m a Research Software Engineer in the Research Software Engineering Team within the Computer Science Department. I’m not hear today to talk to you about software, but about building an Open Scholarship Community in Sheffield.
By way of background I studied Zoology and Genetics back in 95-98 here at Sheffield, then Post-graduate research in Genetic Epidemiology 00-01. I’ve worked as a Genetics Statistician for 10 years at University of Manchester, Western Australia and back here in Sheffield University and then spent a decade working as a Medical Statistician in the Clinical Trials Unit within ScHARR. I had a few years working in industry on Teletmatics before returning to University of Sheffield last year to the role I’m currently in.
I developed an early interest in reproducibility many years ago when I quickly tired of re-creating tables and copying and pasting figures into documents and taught myself literate programming with LaTeX and in time other systems. Despite being author on a number of papers that are Open Access and adopting Git to version control my code during my time working as a Medical Statistician the code that underpinned the research was never formally published.
I’m passionate about open science and saw an opportunity to learn more and help innovate via Open Science Communities and am here to talk that today.

title: Open Scholarship Community Sheffield
text:
INOSC
OSCs are part of International Network of Open Science Communities (INOSC)








Open Science Communities are part of the International Network of Open Science Communities, this started in the Netherlands at Utrecht but grew organically, spreading to other universities within the Netherlands who came together under the umbrella of OSC NL but it has grown beyond just one country and there are now local branches in other countries such as Eire, Saudi Arabia, Sweden and Lisbon.
They’re keen to grow the network further and that is the purpose of the OSC Incubator Programme that I signed up to recently and have been participating in for three weeks now.

OSC Incubator Programme

There are nine participants in this cohort of the OSC Incubator Programme including myself with researches from Greece, Portugal, France and Germany
The stated the aim is to seed, nurture and help grow Open Science/Scholarship Communities around the world.

title: Open Scholarship Community Sheffield
text:
Why Communities?

Nosek (2019) Strategy for Culture Change

This is a diagram from an article by Brian Nosek, one of the co-founders of the Center for Open Science and represents how to bring about culture and behaviour change.
Infrastructure is at the base of the pyramid of culture and behaviour change and there are systems in place such as the Open Science Framework and Octopus which is being developed by JISC. Both of which allow (or will) researchers to register their studies, share materials and data (optionally protecting sensitive data) and share outcomes at any point in the study to accelerate communication regardless of publication.
The user interface and experience of using these tools needs to be low friction to encourage adoption and many popular services such as GitHub and Docker are integrated.
From the top of the pyramid is policy and incentives which address the reward system and these are changing towards incentivising open research practices, but we’re not there yet as these practices are not the norm within many places and it is communities that help bridge or fill this gap. Because when people see others undertaking and engaging with open research practices in a visible manner it helps accelerate adoption.

title: Open Scholarship Community Sheffield
text:
What are Communities?
“a dynamic, social grouping where members align around a shared purpose (or multiple overlapping purposes) and participate in a shared culture. Active community participation frequently aligns with a sense of belonging and affiliation to the community. In a community the flow of information is multi-directional with members able to do something as a result of being connected to one another that they would not be able to do alone.”

I think before going further its worth defining what a community is and this quote from the Center for Scientific Collaboration and Community Engagement gives a clear definition.

title: Open Scholarship Community Sheffield
text:
What are Communities? (cont.)

Shared Goals
Sense of Belonging
Connections
Opportunity


Nurturing a community within Sheffield and as part of the wider INOSC brings together people with shared goals and gives them a sense of belonging. It allows people to make connections and gives them opportunities to learn and grow, which encourages and enables them to take action.

title: Open Scholarship Community Sheffield
text:
Diffusion of Innovation


When any innovative technology or practice comes along you will typically encounter this sort of pattern of diffusion where there are a few innovators who develop the system, slightly more early adopters will pick things up soon after, and following them there is the early majority where uptake really picks up. Unfortunately there is still a large proportion of people who have a propensity to resist, some low, the late majority, some higher, the laggards.
By normalising open research practices through building of an active community we accelerate and lower the bar to reaching the early and late majority and the laggards.

title: Open Scholarship Community Sheffield
text:
Connecting People

Range of career stages and skills/knowledge/experience.
Support beyond training courses.
Sharing knowledge between researchers to learn from each other.


When one person teaches, two people learn.

There are a range of researchers in terms of career stages, early, mid and advanced and across each of these there is variation in the skills, knowledge and experience around the different areas of Open Science, some people have experience in publishing study protocols, others in publishing data on Sheffield ORDA, yet others such as myself have familiarity with the FAIR Principles for Research Software and applying these to publishing open source software projects.
Sharing this knowledge directly between researchers so they learn from each other is a highly effective means of normalising the practices and when one person teaches two people learn.
Training courses are great for getting started but typically when applying what you’ve learned to your own domain/work/problem there will be problems that crop up and this is where the support of a community comes in really helpful as you know where to look for people who can help.
Having physical meetings is an important key feature, but can be augmented by having online forum of some description that allows a permanent record of problems solving to be built up and searched and serve as a basis for developing more formal documentation that needs improving or creating if for example many people meet a problem/barrier when trying to use a service such as ORDA this could be recognised if there are lots of people asking questions or needing support on that front.

title: Open Scholarship Community Sheffield
text:
The Power of Peer-to-Peer

Less intimidating
Experience > Expertise
Practical > Theoretical
Specificity
Participation is the key


Peer-to-peer teaching can be far less intimidating than formal teaching environments and it lowers the threshold for asking for help when it is felt that the community is supportive and encouraging.
Very often experience is more important than expertise. I speak from experience that knowing a system really well means that you can often overlook certain aspects that you take for granted and that someone new to a system might struggle to understand or use. When I started learning to use Git for version control collaboratively my colleagues talked about it as though I already understood what rebasing was, but it was a completely new concept coming from a situation where I had only ever used Git on my own.
In a similar vein sharing practical experience of how to use tools is often more beneficial than deep theoretical explanations. There can often be many aspects that might be covered in theoretical material that aren’t relevant to someone getting started.
In the same vein the more specific a topic is the better, it ensure that the necessary detail is covered and that it is relevant to those attending which improves engagement.
They key to the community really is about participation though and peer-to-peer interactions help promote this.

title: Open Scholarship Community Sheffield
text:
Structure

Core Team of active members, inclusive and diverse.
Independent, bottom-up, self-governing, self-steering.
Not determined by institutional policies.
Collaborate with institutional Open Research programmes, libraries and so forth.
Work with existing groups…

FAIR Roadmap Working Group
Reproducibilitea
Data Visualisation Hub

All staff, researchers, support staff and administrators.


The governance or structure of the Open Scholarship Community consists of a core team of active members which should be inclusive and diverse, with members from all faculties represented. Members in specific domains are better positioned to engage with and inspire their peers. It is important to have representatives from all faculties to encourage wide-spread adoption and avoid any one group from feeling excluded or that Open Scholarship isn’t for them.
The community is meant to be an independent, bottom-up, self-governing and self-steering group, not determined by institutional policies but should cooperate with the existing structures for Open Research, library efforts and so forth and should work with existing groups such as the FAIR Roadmap Working Group, Reproucibilitea and the Data Visualisation hub to name but a few.
Its aimed at all staff, not just researchers but support staff and administrators.

title: Open Scholarship Community Sheffield
text:
Activities and Formats



Members have profiles pages highlighting experience.
Workshops on specific topics.
Establish online forum.
Reuse material and knowledge from existing OSCs.






People who participate in the OSC should each have a profile page and here you can see an example from a member at Utrecht University. This makes it easy for people to find others who have experience in an area they are looking to learn more about.
Further regular workshops on different topics would be undertaken allowing people not just to learn about different aspects of open research but to meet and chat to others working in the area. Its important to have the opportunity to meet and talk in an informal setting as it can lead to useful collaboration and cross-pollination.
To augment this it would be useful to have a forum for asking and answering questions of the community about different topics. This would over time develop a consistent set of material which could be referenced and underpin the development of more structured and formal documentation such as FAQs on particular topics.
Perhaps one of the most useful aspects of joining the International Network of Open Science Communities is that there are other groups who have already gone through the experience of setting up communities and we can tap into that knowledge base as sharing of material and experiences is strongly encouraged and my experience so far from the course is that Loek and Annita who are running it are really passionate and supportive about community building.

title: Open Scholarship Community Sheffield
text:
OSC Sheffield

Opportunity join growing INOSC
Sheffield and Durham currently on Incubator Programme
Present if not launch around OpenFest2023


This gives us an opportunity to join the growing network of Open Science Communities that co-ordinate and share knowledge as part of the International Network of Open Science Communities.
Currently on the Incubator programme from the UK are myself and Fuschia Sirois from the University of Durham, she also happens to be an alumni of The University of Sheffield.
Not currently seeking any costing for this work its something I’ve undertaken of my own volition as I’m keen to see Open Research be more widely adopted and normalised within the research community as I feel there is still a long way to go and that building a community of people to support each other is an effective means of normalising the practice and increasing the open ness of research at The University of Sheffield and beyond.
